title: Is this Tiny Altcoin Linked To a Fintech Giant? [HUGE If it’s True]

chunks.text:
Here's something that shouldn't really happen. A 
public AI agent appears online and starts talking   about ideas that later show up in a confidential 
investor letter. And instead of being shut down,   it's quietly tolerated. In this video, we're 
going to walk through documents, on-chain data,   and observable behavior, separating what we 
can verify from what we can't. And by the end,   you can decide whether this is just a 
coincidence or did the best fintech firm   of the last 15 years stealth launch a little 
frog meme. This video is for information   and entertainment only. It reflects my 
personal opinions and is not financial   advice. Check the description for more 
information. Always do your own research. To fully understand why this is even worth 
looking at, we first have to understand who   this VC firm is. Ribbit Capital. Ribbit is not 
a crypto fund. They're one of the most important   fintech venture firms in the last 15 years. They were early in Stripe, Coinbase, Nubank,   Revolut. The list is stacked. Just check it 
out. Their focus has always been financial   infrastructure. Stuff like payments, identity, 
compliance, rails, trust. And importantly,   Ribbit has a long history of building very 
quietly. They don't announce ideas early. They don't hype experiments. They let 
things exist before they explain them. Ribbit's co-founder Micky Malka has been 
consistent about one thing for decades. He tends to focus less on products and more 
on systems. He bought Bitcoin early but not   as a trade. He bought it because he was 
interested in what programmable money   could become. He backed Robinhood before it 
worked and saved them when they almost died,   and he focused on access to finance long 
before it became fashionable to do so. It helps to understand the kind of long-term 
thinking this firm, and especially Micky,   are known for. Micky has been consistent on 
one idea for years: Money on its own is not   enough. But for the next decade, money without 
knowledge is not money. It's not valuable anymore. What do you mean by that? If money 
has no knowledge of what it's doing,   it has no smart contract. It has no rules. It has no decision tree that was made to   move it from one place to another. It doesn't 
hold that information. It's not valuable. What matters is money plus decision-making. And 
that framing shows up again and again in Ribbit's   investments. And if you follow the logic all the 
way through, the natural endpoint isn't apps,   it's agents. And that's the direction of travel 
Micky has been openly talking about for years. One of the first questions people always 
ask when they see this story: If it's real,   why wouldn't Ribbit just say it? And the 
answer is simple. Stealth is normal for   Ribbit. They've repeatedly backed companies 
that stayed private early, avoided hype,   and only surfaced once the infrastructure was 
ready. It isn't secrecy for fun. It's protection. Protection from being copied, premature 
regulation, and the story outrunning the product. Underpinning everything that follows is a 
document that Ribbit circulated in 2024,   and it's known as the Identity Letter. The 
letter isn't the story in and of itself. It's   the foundation for understanding 
Ribbit's worldview. Without it,   nothing else in this investigation makes 
sense. At the time, it was confidential,   shared privately with partners and LPs. And three 
ideas run through the entire document. First,   identity comes before access. Today, you log 
in with your usernames and your passwords. Ribbit's view is that this breaks down at scale. Instead, systems ask, "Who are you? What can you   prove? And what are you authorized to do?" Access 
becomes automatic based on credentials, not login. Second, software begins to act on your behalf. Right now, you manually click buttons. Ribbit's   view is that this changes. You set rules once and 
software executes decisions for you. Paying bills,   booking flights, moving money, running checks. You're not involved every time. The system acts   with permissions you've already approved. Third, 
infrastructure matters more than interfaces. Most people focus on apps, what things look 
like. Ribbit focuses on what sits underneath:   permissions, enforcements, settlement. Those 
invisible systems matter more than the screen   you tap. And that's where Ribbit invests. This 
letter is Ribbit explaining how the world has to   work before any products can exist. And crucially, 
it exists before anything else in the story. There is one more factual detail that 
sits alongside the Identity Letter. In US SEC filings, an entity named Tibbir 
Trust appears as a reporting holder. Now,   these filings are not commentary or 
marketing material. They're formal   disclosures required under US securities 
laws. In those disclosures, Tibbir Trust   is listed as holding equity in Robinhood 
alongside other Ribbit-related entities.

So,   these filings specify (a) the existence of the 
trust, (b) its status as a reporting entity,   and (c) its ownership of publicly listed shares. It's the fact that Tibbir is the name of a real   pre-existing legal entity used in regulated 
disclosures connected to Ribbit's ecosystem. After the Identity Letter had been circulating, 
an AI agent appears publicly launched on a   platform called Virtuals. Virtuals is a 
platform where agents are deployed as an   entire system. So an agent is launched 
with a token and it's launched with a   Twitter account that the agent controls. In this case, the agent is called Tibbir,   and it posts publicly on Twitter under the Twitter 
handle Ribbit A20. From the outside, the agent is   not presented as being part of Ribbit. There's 
no branding, no claim of affiliation. There's   no hype. There's no token promotion. And at 
this stage, there's nothing really to suggest   that Ribbit is behind this. All we can say 
factually is that the agent appears after the   Identity Letter. It posts publicly to Twitter and 
its language closely mirrors the kind of systems   thinking Ribbit had already laid out internally. That alignment on its own doesn't prove anything. Maybe it got hold of the confidential Identity 
Letter and started circulating the information. But looking deeper, there seems to be an on-chain 
footprint that connects Micky and the agent. Everything we've looked at could be coincidence. But the beauty of blockchain is that everything is   verifiable. When you look at the wallet associated 
with a Tibbir agent deployment, one thing clearly   stands out. This wallet was directly funded by 
Micky Malka. Now, that fact alone doesn't prove   who controls Micky Malka. ENS names are not 
legal entities, and we should be careful with   assumptions. So, instead of guessing, we can just 
follow where that wallet actually goes. The ENS   name for Micky Malka is part of the same on-chain 
cluster as Canvas. And Canvas controls a vault   called Canvas Vault. And vault ENSs are typically 
used to hold high-value assets, right? And if we   look inside this vault, we can see the CryptoPunk 
that Micky Malka uses as his PFP is inside this   vault. The vault's also got an additional 25 
other CryptoPunks. Just as an aside, Micky Malka   actually owns the CryptoPunk IP via a nonprofit 
organization called Node. They acquired them off   Yuga Labs. Just know that Micky Malka really likes 
Punks. He really likes art. He really likes Punks. Just quickly guys, I want to tell you about 
Easy Bitcoin. This segment is sponsored by Easy   Bitcoin. They're part of the EasyGroup family 
and Easy Bitcoin operates a recurring purchase   service for Bitcoin. The service functions through 
scheduled card payments at user-defined intervals. Upon processing payment, the company purchases 
Bitcoin and transfers it to a user-specified   address. The service operates in a non-custodial 
basis, meaning purchased Bitcoin is sent directly   to the user's controlled wallet without being held 
on the platform. This means users can choose how   much they want to DCA, how frequently they want 
to DCA, and it's never held by Easy Bitcoin. It's   always held in the user's own wallet. Easy Bitcoin 
is not available in the UK. And this information   is provided for educational purposes only and does

was confidential at the time, shared privately   with LPs before any public release. Unlike 
the Identity Letter, this one wasn't abstract. It describes specific mechanics: how agents 
are instantiated, how tokens attach to agents,   how identity, memory, and expertise are 
represented, and how trust and permissions   are enforced programmatically.

Capital portfolio company. And this matters,   right? Because if the agent had been fake, 
misleading, or problematic, you would reasonably   expect some distance. Instead, the infrastructure 
was used and the mint proceeded. The mint also   drew a bunch of public reaction. Ever Alonzo 
from Ribbit Capital reacted to it publicly. Now, this agent is actually followed by basically 
everybody inside Ribbit Capital. A few months ago,   Ribbit wiped their public presence clean. They 
overhauled their entire website and deleted every   single old tweet. And the new site introduced two 
symbols that immediately stood out. The first was   a silver coin. If we inspect the webpage, we can 
see that this is called Ribbitcoin. And visually,   it looks almost identical to the NFT that 
had already been issued to Tibbir holders   by the agent. It's the same form, same color, 
same structure. It just looks like the other   face of the coin. Now, it's not identical. It can easily be a mistake. It almost looks   like two sides of the same object. The NFT 
came first. The website imagery came later. The second change was a little more subtle. Ribbit introduced a backwards "R" into its   visual language. No claim being made again, but 
people notice that Tibbir is simply Ribbit spelled   backwards. And the reversed "R" suddenly feels 
like, oh, you can literally read "Tibbir" inside   their website in the top right-hand corner. So, just this week, Ribbit released a brand   new four-part promo video. And in this video, it 
looks like there's a bunch of Easter eggs that   have been left. Again, I'm going to show you what 
they are. Make up your own mind as to whether or   not they are actual Easter eggs or just random 
coincidences. The story follows a girl traveling   on a train from destination to destination. Now, 
quite clearly, this train is representing rails,   but you've got a girl carrying credentials, moving 
on this train from destination to destination with   credentials. Each destination is a Ribbit Capital

infrastructure, the rails that connect it all is a   frog. Who knows what that means? But you've got
